Dun-vested Twilight now along the sky,</br>With tardy-moving pace, begins to creep;</br>Toward their solemn gloom-wrap'd mansions fly</br>The ebon rooks, spread o'er the mountain steep.

And now from Stygian cave, would haggard night</br>Throw her deep horrors o'er the shuddering ground,</br>Did not pale Cynthia give a lurid light</br>Through the thick clouds which gird th' horizon round.
Soul-sad'ning stillness lulls the pensive air,</br>Save that from far, with awe-impressing knowl,</br>The swinging bell keep stated time I hear,</br>Slowly-responsive to the clamant owl:
Now, melancholy musing, takes her fill,</br>Alone from distant home doth she remain,</br>With faintly-falling foot winds up the hill,</br>Or plods along the solitary plain.
Where this bald barren spot of earth expands,</br>Deck'd with no shade of plant, or flow'rets smile,</br>Rear'd by some skill-conducted artist's hands,</br>A gallows frowns, a terror-striking pile.
Full of the nurse, his fell of hair erect,</br>The late returning school-boy dreads to pass;</br>And far around (unless her swain protect)</br>Wanders the rural simple-minded lass.
Yet underneath does contemplation sit,</br>Leaning her cheek against the dewy post;</br>And tho' the moisture down her bosom flit,</br>She heeds it not, in deep reflection lost.
How many hapless mortal beings here,</br>In hempen string, have dangled out of life,</br>Ne'er laid upon the consecrated bier,</br>But given to the surgeon's ruthless knife!
Some, whose blank minds, no spark of mercy knew,</br>To horrid deeds of desperation slow,</br>And driv'n by hot-brain'd frenzy not a few,</br>To lift their hands, and strike the fatal blow.
Here pettyfogging forgery has oft</br>Its due desert, and last sad tremors felt:</br>Here window-scaling elves have swung aloft;</br>And rape has dy'd, for deeds he never dealt.
Here thieves of every size, and every sort,</br>Who, once firm-joined in many a social gang,</br>Dar'd with the legislative pow'r to sport,</br>At various times, in various numbers hang.
Of graceful mein the highway-robber, here,</br>Who, mounted bravely on his gallant steed,</br>Could a whole caravan half-kill with fear,</br>Nor youth can save, nor valour's hardy deed.
Yet not unmourn'd, he pass'd along the road,</br>On the slow-dragging cart exalted high,</br>Caught by his form, the virgin's bosom glow'd,</br>And tearful pity stole into her eye.
Ah!  why would she behold this dismal sight?</br>Ah!  why her young unharden'd breast expose?</br>Beside her couch, all the dead hours of night,</br>His ghost shall stand, and banish her repose.
But curiosity with fluttering wing,</br>Idle awakener of the human breast,</br>Perhaps of knowledge too the fruitful spring,</br>In every human bosom reigns confest.
Lost to itself th' incurious shade,</br>Some novel scenes th' excursive mind requires,</br>Confin'd the active principle would fade,</br>Its ardour wasted, and extinct its fires.
Hence birth-night balls, and coronations proud,</br>Hence wax-work puppets draw the gazing eye,</br>Hence the Lord May'r's and his processive crowd,</br>And hapless thieves whose destiny is nigh.
Nor you ye rich, and haughty of the earth,</br>Look on these humble lays with eye askance;</br>Perhaps you owe to accident and birth,</br>That you not share with them their airy dance.
The murd'rer deaf to pity's whisp'ring breath,</br>Had he been born a ruler of mankind,</br>Haply o'er half the globe had scatter'd death,</br>And nations prais'd his high heroic mind.
The statesman, planted in their meaner sphere,</br>Untouch'd the wealth of an impoverish'd land,</br>The nightly thiev'ry with superior share</br>Of deep-directing policy had plann'd.
For sunk in low estate, the Fates deny'd</br>To them the broken laws, and venial sin,</br>Safe by the whirl the larger vessels ride,</br>Whose waves devouring draw the smaller in.
Of nice dependencies is form'd the scale,</br>Each imperceptible gradation just,</br>From those who scarce may breathe the common gale,</br>To those who perpetrate whate'er they lust.
For me, howbeit a sagely-singing wight,</br>These mysteries to others I consign,</br>Enough for me, that, in this dusky night,</br>The melancholy garland I intwine.
Enough for me, that, while I tune the lay</br>In which these ill-starr'd suff'rers I bemoan,</br>My thoughts pace dark reflections mazy way,</br>And their sad exit warns me of my own.
Yes, all must drink the draught which death shall pour,</br>Nor I'll my loitering lips in vain refuse,</br>Yet come when will the courage-chilling hour,</br>Kind Heav'n forbid my dying in my shoes!
Ye soft Parnassian maids defend your bard,</br>Nor let him to his grave go down with shame;</br>He doth not feel one wish by dying bard,</br>Among th' applauding crowd to gain a name.
Should you your sacred care remove, alas!</br>And meagre hunger urge him to a crime,</br>Should dire necessity bring this to pass,</br>And he be blasted in his vernal prime:
This on his grave be writ, that all may view:</br>Here lyes a luckless youth, whose ready quill</br>The fairy face of nature nicely drew,</br>And wrote quaint elegies with matchless skill:
But ah!  by these he earn'd a scanty fare,</br>Though fraught with genius they were cast aside,</br>He hir'd a purse, he could not feed on air,</br>And, rather than by famine perish, dy'd.

Great Rogues may thrive — and candour's self must own,</br>Strong the temptation was, and small the fault;</br>Be then to time his virtues only known,</br>The cause and manner of his death forgot.</br>
